<!--This article is about the protests, with a minimum of background information for context. If you want to add substantial content about the complex domestic response by Egypt's government, please do it at [Domestic responses to the 2011 Egyptian protests]. For international responses, go to [International reactions to the 2011 Egyptian protests]. Such content added here will likely be moved or removed. -->
â
The '''Egyptian Revolution of 2011''' ({{lang-ar|Ø§ÙØ«ÙØ±Ø© Ø§ÙÙØµØ±ÙØ© Ø³ÙØ© 2011}} ''al-Thawrah al-Miá¹£riyyah sanat 2011''), sometimes called the '''25 January Revolution''' ({{lang|ar|Ø«ÙØ±Ø© 25 ÙÙØ§ÙØ±}} ''Thawrat 25 YanÄyir''),<ref>{{cite news|journal=[[Al-Ahram]] Weekly|title=The 25 January Revolution (Special issue)|date=10â16 February 2011|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2011/1034/special.htm|accessdate=February 15, 2011}}</ref> the '''Revolution of the Youth''' ({{lang|ar|Ø«ÙØ±Ø© Ø§ÙØ´Ø¨Ø§Ø¨}} ''Thawrat al-ShabÄb'') or the '''White Revolution''' ({{lang|ar|Ø§ÙØ«ÙØ±Ø© Ø§ÙØ¨ÙØ¶Ø§Ø¡}} ''al-Thawrah al-bayá¸ÄÊ¾''), is a [[social movement]] that began in [[Egypt]] on 25 January 2011, characterised by a series of street [[political demonstration|demonstrations]], marches, [[political rally|rallies]], acts of [[civil disobedience]], riots, labour strikes, and violent clashes; the date was selected to coincide with the [[National Police Day (Egypt)|National Police Day]]. The protests were largest in [[Cairo]] and [[Alexandria]], with significant activities in other cities of Egypt.<ref name="AFP-egyptbraces" /> At times over a million people were protesting to demand the overthrow of the [[Egyptian President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]], an end to corruption and police repression, and democratic reforms of the political system.<ref>[http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/net-down-special-forces-deployed-in-cairo-as-egypt-braces-for-protests/story-e6frg6so-1225996200388 "Net down, special forces deployed in Cairo as Egypt braces for protests"] - ''News Limited'' - Retrieved 1 February 2011.</ref> The demonstrations and other actions in Egypt in this period were part of a campaign of [[civil resistance]], a technique of struggle relying primarily on non-violent methods. On 11 February, Mubarak resigned from office as a result of determined popular protest.<ref>{{cite news|journal=Wall Street Journal|title=Fall of Mubarak Shakes Middle East|date=February 12, 2011|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703786804576137543866154926.html|accessdate=February 12, 2011}}</ref> While localized protests had been common in previous years, the 2011 protests have been the largest demonstrations seen in Egypt since the [[1977 Egyptian Bread Riots|1977 Bread Riots]] and unprecedented in scope,<ref name="Dan Murphy 0125">{{Cite news|last=Murphy|first=Dan|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Backchannels/2011/0125/Inspired-by-Tunisia-Egypt-s-protests-appear-unprecedented|title=Inspired by Tunisia, Egypt's protests appear unprecedented|work=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|date=25 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> drawing participants from a variety of [[socio-economic]] backgrounds and religions.<ref name="nyt-fahim">{{Cite news|first=Kareem|last=Fahim|coauthors=El-Nagaar, Mona|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/26/world/middleeast/26egypt.html|title=Violent Clashes Mark Protests Against Mubarakâs Rule|work=The New York Times | date=25 January 2011| accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
+
The '''Egyptian Revolution of 2011''' ({{lang-ar|Ø§ÙØ«ÙØ±Ø© Ø§ÙÙØµØ±ÙØ© Ø³ÙØ© 2011}} ''al-Thawrah al-Miá¹£riyyah sanat 2011''), is a [[social movement]] that began in [[Egypt]] on 25 January 2011, characterised by a series of street [[political demonstration|demonstrations]], marches, [[political rally|rallies]], acts of [[civil disobedience]], riots, labour strikes, and violent clashes; the date was selected to coincide with the [[National Police Day (Egypt)|National Police Day]]. The protests were largest in [[Cairo]] and [[Alexandria]], with significant activities in other cities of Egypt.<ref name="AFP-egyptbraces" /> At times over a million people were protesting to demand the overthrow of the [[Egyptian President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]], an end to corruption and police repression, and democratic reforms of the political system.<ref>[http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/net-down-special-forces-deployed-in-cairo-as-egypt-braces-for-protests/story-e6frg6so-1225996200388 "Net down, special forces deployed in Cairo as Egypt braces for protests"] - ''News Limited'' - Retrieved 1 February 2011.</ref> The demonstrations and other actions in Egypt in this period were part of a campaign of [[civil resistance]], a technique of struggle relying primarily on non-violent methods. On 11 February, Mubarak resigned from office as a result of determined popular protest.<ref>{{cite news|journal=Wall Street Journal|title=Fall of Mubarak Shakes Middle East|date=February 12, 2011|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703786804576137543866154926.html|accessdate=February 12, 2011}}</ref> While localized protests had been common in previous years, the 2011 protests have been the largest demonstrations seen in Egypt since the [[1977 Egyptian Bread Riots|1977 Bread Riots]] and unprecedented in scope,<ref name="Dan Murphy 0125">{{Cite news|last=Murphy|first=Dan|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Backchannels/2011/0125/Inspired-by-Tunisia-Egypt-s-protests-appear-unprecedented|title=Inspired by Tunisia, Egypt's protests appear unprecedented|work=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|date=25 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> drawing participants from a variety of [[socio-economic]] backgrounds and religions.<ref name="nyt-fahim">{{Cite news|first=Kareem|last=Fahim|coauthors=El-Nagaar, Mona|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/26/world/middleeast/26egypt.html|title=Violent Clashes Mark Protests Against Mubarakâs Rule|work=The New York Times | date=25 January 2011| accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
The demonstrations, part of the [[2010â2011 Arab world protests]], started in the weeks after similar [[2010-2011 Tunisian uprising|events in Tunisia]], with many protesters carrying Tunisian flags as a symbol of their influence.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Eltahawy|first=Mona|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/25/AR2011012507200.html|title=Will Egypt's Protests Go the Way of Tunisia's Revolution?|work=The Washington Post |date=26 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> Grievances of Egyptian protesters have focused on legal and political issues<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/1473531/Q&A--What-s-behind-the-unrest-|title=Q&A: What's Behind the Unrest?|publisher=SBS|date=27 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> including [[police brutality]],<ref name="AFP-egyptbraces">{{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110125-egypt-braces-nationwide-protests|title=Egypt braces for nationwide protests|author=AFP|publisher=France24|date=25 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> [[Emergency law in Egypt|state of emergency]] laws,<ref name="AFP-egyptbraces" /> lack of [[free elections]] and [[freedom of speech]],<ref name="alarabiya-plans" /> and uncontrollable corruption,<ref name="alarabiya-plans">{{Cite news|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/01/27/135207.html|title=Egypt activists plan biggest protest yet on Friday|work=[[Al Arabiya]]|date=27 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> as well as economic issues including high unemployment,<ref name="tna">{{Cite news|url=http://www.thenewage.co.za/8894-1007-53-Egypt_protests_a_ticking_time_bomb_Analysts|title=Egypt protests a ticking time bomb: Analysts|author=AFP|publisher=The New Age|date=27 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> [[food inflation|food price inflation]],<ref name="tna" /> and low [[minimum wage]]s.<ref name="AFP-egyptbraces" /><ref name="tna" /> The primary demands from protest organizers are the end of the [[Hosni Mubarak]] regime, the end of Emergency Law (martial law), freedom, justice, a responsive non-military government, and management of Egypt's resources.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2011/01/egyptian-activists-action-plan-translated/70388/|title=Egyptian Activists' Action Plan: Translated|work=[[The Atlantic]]|date=27 January 2011}}</ref> Labour unions were said to play an integral part in the protests.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.defenddemocracy.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=11792083&Itemid=347 |title=Trade unions: the revolutionary social network at play in Egypt and Tunisia |publisher=Defenddemocracy.org |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>
The demonstrations, part of the [[2010â2011 Arab world protests]], started in the weeks after similar [[2010-2011 Tunisian uprising|events in Tunisia]], with many protesters carrying Tunisian flags as a symbol of their influence.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Eltahawy|first=Mona|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/25/AR2011012507200.html|title=Will Egypt's Protests Go the Way of Tunisia's Revolution?|work=The Washington Post |date=26 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> Grievances of Egyptian protesters have focused on legal and political issues<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/1473531/Q&A--What-s-behind-the-unrest-|title=Q&A: What's Behind the Unrest?|publisher=SBS|date=27 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> including [[police brutality]],<ref name="AFP-egyptbraces">{{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110125-egypt-braces-nationwide-protests|title=Egypt braces for nationwide protests|author=AFP|publisher=France24|date=25 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> [[Emergency law in Egypt|state of emergency]] laws,<ref name="AFP-egyptbraces" /> lack of [[free elections]] and [[freedom of speech]],<ref name="alarabiya-plans" /> and uncontrollable corruption,<ref name="alarabiya-plans">{{Cite news|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/01/27/135207.html|title=Egypt activists plan biggest protest yet on Friday|work=[[Al Arabiya]]|date=27 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> as well as economic issues including high unemployment,<ref name="tna">{{Cite news|url=http://www.thenewage.co.za/8894-1007-53-Egypt_protests_a_ticking_time_bomb_Analysts|title=Egypt protests a ticking time bomb: Analysts|author=AFP|publisher=The New Age|date=27 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> [[food inflation|food price inflation]],<ref name="tna" /> and low [[minimum wage]]s.<ref name="AFP-egyptbraces" /><ref name="tna" /> The primary demands from protest organizers are the end of the [[Hosni Mubarak]] regime, the end of Emergency Law (martial law), freedom, justice, a responsive non-military government, and management of Egypt's resources.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2011/01/egyptian-activists-action-plan-translated/70388/|title=Egyptian Activists' Action Plan: Translated|work=[[The Atlantic]]|date=27 January 2011}}</ref> Labour unions were said to play an integral part in the protests.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.defenddemocracy.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=11792083&Itemid=347 |title=Trade unions: the revolutionary social network at play in Egypt and Tunisia |publisher=Defenddemocracy.org |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>

== Naming ==
== Naming ==
â
{{Empty section|date=February 2011}}
+
In Egypt and the wider Arab world the protests, and change in government, is sometimes called the '''25 January Revolution''' ({{lang|ar|Ø«ÙØ±Ø© 25 ÙÙØ§ÙØ±}} ''Thawrat 25 YanÄyir''),<ref>{{cite news|journal=[[Al-Ahram]] Weekly|title=The 25 January Revolution (Special issue)|date=10â16 February 2011|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2011/1034/special.htm|accessdate=February 15, 2011}}</ref> the '''Revolution of the Youth''' ({{lang|ar|Ø«ÙØ±Ø© Ø§ÙØ´Ø¨Ø§Ø¨}} ''Thawrat al-ShabÄb'') or the '''White Revolution''' ({{lang|ar|Ø§ÙØ«ÙØ±Ø© Ø§ÙØ¨ÙØ¶Ø§Ø¡}} ''al-Thawrah al-bayá¸ÄÊ¾'').
